awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium:  Automatic Control Driven Resource Management in Chip Multiprocessors
awd_abstract_narration:
Future computer architectures will execute critical applications ranging from climate modeling to bioinformatics to simulations of new materials. Emerging chip multiprocessors are novel architectures that provide high performance and low power consumption. When multiple applications share the same chip multiprocessor, proper management of architectural resources becomes a critical problem. This research targets inter-application management of different types of resources found in a chip multiprocessor using robust and resilient techniques drawn from formal feedback control theory. It enables applications to satisfy their performance requirements and, at the same time, maximizes the utilization of hardware resources. 

This research helps to make the transition from conventional architectures to chip multiprocessors smoother, and as a result, maximizes the number of critical applications that can take advantage of these emerging architectures. The transfer of the technology being developed to IBM and HP Labs allows serious testing of the proposed strategies in large-scale architectures built from chip multiprocessors. The results from this project not only present an accurate assessment of feedback control theory in a new domain, but also get integrated into two important software infrastructures, Singularity and Xen, both used extensively by large research communities. This research also accommodates two efforts in broadening participation, CISE Visit in Engineering Weekends (VIEW) and NASA-Aerospace Education Services Project (NASA-AESP) at the Center for Science and the Schools (CSATS).

por.por_cntn:
With the emergence of multicore and manycore systems, maximizing the performance of important applications, e.g., those from astrophysics, computational chemistry and bioinformatics domains, on these architectures has been a top priority. To address this problem, one needs to manage multiple computation, communication and storage resources in a computing system in an optimal fashion. This project took a step toward that direction, by proposing, designing, implementing and finally experimentally evaluating various resource management strategies based on well-established automatic control theory based principles.

The results from this project not only demonstrated the feasibility of employing automatic control theory for resource management on emerging parallel computing architectures, but also highlighted the unique benefits of this theory in that domain. In particular, the project revealed the importance of being able to provide performance guarantees, a feature enabled by automatic control. It also allowed researchers to provide theoretical proofs for some aspects of their designs. As a result, the techniques proposed in this research were able to significantly improve over the state-of-the-art ad-hoc resource management strategies, leading, in some cases, to performance improvements as high as 50%, in modern parallel computing systems. This project also revealed that automatic control theory based resource management strategies can be implemented in hardware, in software or in a hardware-software cooperative fashion, and each of these options can, to a certain extent, be integrated with existing resource management strategies used in industry.

This project trained a total of 10 PhD students, and contributed to a simulation infrastructure for conducting computer architecture research.  More importantly, the project enabled graduate students to better understand the complex resource management problem in emerging manycore systems, and helped them develop various end-to-end solutions. The outcomes of the individual sub-projects have been discussed in various courses the PIs teach at Penn State. The project also presented a challenging problem, namely resource management in manycores, to the automatic control theory community. In fact, many aspects of this problem required unique solutions in that domain (e.g., custom feedback controller designs instead of more traditional ones used in control theory).
